title: Cyclonic Circulation to Form Over Bay of Bengal by October 10, IMD Issues Yellow Warning for Odisha - pragativadi.com
article_text:
A new cyclonic circulation is expected to develop over the north Bay of Bengal by October 10, according to the Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Bhubaneswar. However, officials clarified that the system is unlikely to intensify significantly.

Thunderstorms and Rain Likely in Odisha

Despite the weak system, moderate rainfall with thunderstorms and lightning is likely to continue across several parts of Odisha in the next few days.

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) stated that the southwest monsoon’s withdrawal from the state may get delayed. It was earlier expected around October 15, but current conditions remain unfavourable for its retreat in the next five days.

Meteorologists said that gradual changes in wind direction could soon create favourable conditions for the monsoon withdrawal from western Odisha.

Yellow Warning Issued for 24 Districts

The weather office has issued a yellow warning for 24 districts, including: Malkangiri, Koraput, Khordha, Puri, Cuttack, and Kendrapara.

Residents in these regions have been advised to stay alert to possible thunderstorms and lightning.

For October 10, a statewide yellow alert has been announced, urging citizens across all districts to take precautions.

IMD’s Safety Advisory

The IMD has advised people to:

Avoid sheltering under trees during lightning.

Stay away from open fields and water bodies.

Move indoors immediately if thunder is heard.

These safety measures are crucial as lightning incidents continue to pose risks during this transition period.

title: Hurricane Priscilla Weather Update: Storm Weakens Over Mexico but Brings Heavy Rain, Flood Risks, and U.S. Impacts - el-balad.com
article_text:
NEWS
Hurricane Priscilla Weather Update: Storm Weakens Over Mexico but Brings Heavy Rain, Flood Risks, and U.S. Impacts
The hurricane priscilla weather system, which began as a powerful Pacific hurricane off the coast of Mexico, has now weakened into a tropical storm. Despite losing strength, it continues to pose serious threats with torrential rainfall, strong winds, and the potential for flash flooding across Mexico and parts of the U.S. Southwest.
Bassyonni
ago 6 hours
Hurricane Priscilla
Hurricane Priscilla’s Development and Current Status

Hurricane Priscilla initially intensified rapidly earlier this week, reaching peak sustained winds near 85 mph (140 kph) before cooler waters and stronger upper-level winds caused it to lose strength. By midweek, the system had downgraded to a tropical storm, though it still carried significant rainfall and coastal hazards.

According to meteorologists, Priscilla’s core remains disorganized, but its expansive rainbands are stretching across western Mexico, particularly along the states of Jalisco, Nayarit, Colima, and Baja California Sur.

Key storm statistics at a glance:

Parameter	Detail
Peak wind speed	85 mph (140 kph)
Current classification	Tropical Storm
Affected Mexican states	Jalisco, Nayarit, Michoacán, Colima, Sinaloa, Baja California Sur
Expected U.S. impact areas	Arizona, New Mexico, Nevada, Utah, Colorado
Estimated rainfall totals	2–5 inches (5–13 cm)
Heavy Rain and Flooding Threats in Mexico

Although Priscilla has weakened, its slow movement has increased the rainfall duration across coastal and inland regions. Local authorities have reported flash floods, overflowing rivers, and disrupted transport routes.

In Jalisco, emergency crews are responding to reports of missing individuals swept away by rising waters. Schools in several Pacific states have been suspended, and emergency shelters have been opened to accommodate residents in high-risk areas.

Coastal zones have also faced large waves, dangerous surf, and rip currents, forcing temporary closures of ports such as Cabo San Lucas, La Paz, and Manzanillo.

How the U.S. Southwest Is Preparing for Priscilla’s Remnants

Forecasters expect hurricane priscilla weather to continue weakening as it moves inland over Baja California, but its remnants will push northward into the United States. Moisture from the system is predicted to merge with an upper-level trough, delivering widespread rainfall across the desert Southwest.

Rainfall projections in the U.S. include:

Arizona: Up to 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) in Phoenix, with higher totals in mountainous areas.

New Mexico and Nevada: 1–3 inches (2.5–7.5 cm) expected, especially near higher elevations.

Southern Utah and Colorado: Isolated heavy rain pockets, raising flash flood concerns.

The National Weather Service has issued flash flood watches for several states, emphasizing caution in areas with dry creek beds, canyons, and burn scars prone to rapid flooding.

Wind and Surf Impacts Continue Along Mexico’s Coast

Even as Priscilla transitions into a weaker system, strong gusts and powerful waves continue to batter Mexico’s Pacific coast. Swells several meters high are being recorded, posing a threat to fishermen, beachgoers, and small boats. Coastal authorities have urged residents to avoid beaches until conditions stabilize.

Affected coastal areas:

Cabo San Lucas

Puerto Vallarta

La Paz

Manzanillo

Mazatlán

These regions have experienced both wind damage and temporary power outages, although restoration efforts are already underway.

What’s Next for Priscilla

Weather models suggest that the storm will dissipate completely after crossing the Baja Peninsula. However, its lingering moisture will continue to influence weather patterns over Mexico and the southwestern United States through the weekend.

Meteorologists note that while Priscilla is not expected to regain hurricane strength, its aftermath highlights how even weakening tropical systems can unleash dangerous and long-lasting effects through flooding and landslides.

Residents in both Mexico and the United States are urged to stay updated on official forecasts and heed local safety advisories until the hurricane priscilla weather system fully dissipates.
